review.title: Decentralized Supply Chain Formation: A Market Protocol and Competitive Equilibrium Analysis
review.abstract: Supply chain formation is the process of determining the structure and terms of exchange relationships to enable a multilevel, multiagent production activity. We present a simple model of supply chains, highlighting two characteristic features: hierarchical subtask decomposition, and resource contention. To decentralize the formation process, we introduce a market price system over the resources produced along the chain. In a competitive equilibrium for this system, agents choose locally optimal allocations with respect to prices, and outcomes are optimal overall. To determine prices, we define a market protocol based on distributed, progressive auctions, and myopic, non-strategic agent bidding policies. In the presence of resource contention, this protocol produces better solutions than the greedy protocols common in the artificial intelligence and multiagent systems literature. The protocol often converges to high-value supply chains, and when competitive equilibria exist, typically to approximate competitive equilibria. However, complementarities in agent production technologies can cause the protocol to wastefully allocate inputs to agents that do not produce their outputs. A subsequent decommitment phase recovers a significant fraction of the lost surplus.

sections.heading: 2. The Supply Chain Formation Problem
sections.text: A key feature of our problem model is hierarchical task division: in order to perform a given task, an agent must perform some sub-tasks that can be delegated to other agents, which in turn can have sub-tasks that can be delegated to form a supply chain by splitting up task completion. Task assignment constraints arise from resource conflicts where an agent needs a common resource (such as a task fulfillment or something tangible such as a device) to perform his tasks. Tasks are performed on behalf of a particular agent; if two agents need a task, it would have to be performed twice to satisfy both. In this way, tasks are the same as any other discrete, competing resource. Therefore, in our model we do not distinguish between "good" and "good" to refer to a task or resource provided or required by an agent. In this way, tasks are the same as any other discrete, competing resource.

sections.heading: 2.1 Example: Automotive Supply Chain Formation
sections.text: We illustrate our model of supply chain formation using a stylized, hypothetical example from the automotive industry. Traditionally, automotive supply chains extend over many levels, which are formed and maintained over long periods of time through extensive human negotiation. There is some automation emerging, for example, through Covisint2, a company founded by GM, Ford and DaimlerChrysler to mediate negotiations and exchange of parts and other interactions in the supply chain. Currently, the focus of this effort is on a specific exchange relationship within a single production level. We view the broader issue of multi-level relationships as complete, workable supply chains. In the example shown in Figure 1, Ford and GM must acquire transmission contracts in order to manufacture specific car models. Ford can manufacture the transmissions in its own factories or acquire them from an independent transmission manufacturer. GM currently does not have the ability to produce and outsource the desired transmissions.

sections.heading: 3. Resource Contention
sections.text: A natural candidate approach to the formation of supply chains is the CONTRACT NET Protocol (Davis & Smith, 1983), the most widely studied algorithm for establishing performance relationships between distributed actors. CONTRACT NET actually fits our framework as it uses local negotiations to achieve a hierarchical division of tasks. Although, due to the many variants of CONTRACT NET in the literature, definitive characterization is difficult (Baker, 1996; Davis & Smith, 1983; Dellarocas et al., 2000; Sandholm, 1993), it is fair to say that the "quotation request" comes from the root (right to left from the consumer, in our network terminology), and contract conclusion is bottom to top (left to right from the consumer), with selection at each level among the candidates "offers" being a close decision. (Variants of the protocol are made primarily by the form of bids and selection criteria used, which are easily distinguished as a result).

sections.heading: 5.1 Auction Mechanism
sections.text: The SAMP SB mechanisms include a number of positive or negative offers, one for each commodity. Auctions run simultaneously, asynchronously and independently of each other, with no direct coordination. Agents interact with the auctions by making bids for goods they want to buy or sell. A bid is of the form: (q1 p1). (qn pn) Each pair (qn pn) indicates an offer to buy or sell the commodity, with Qi indicating the quantity of the offer and pi indicating the price. If Qi > 0, it is an offer to buy Qi units of good for no more than pi per unit, and we refer to it as an offer to buy. If Qi < 0, it is an offer to sell Qi units for no less than Pi per unit, and we refer to it as a sale offer. Since no agent sells both buys and the good in a task dependency network, one bid contains either all positive or quantitative offers.

sections.heading: 5.2 Bidding Policies
sections.text: Although the constructors of the negotiation mechanisms generally have no control over the behavior of the agents in the system, they assume that any conclusions about the outcome of a mechanism need only be based on some assumptions about these behaviors. A typical assumption in economics is that the agents are rational in a certain sense, for example, that they are playing strategies that create a balance between producers and Nash. However, as discussed in Section 7.1, our analysis assumes that the agents follow a simple, non-strategic supply policy that is described in this section. Other variations may be reasonable or perhaps better than the strategies we described. Instead of exploring the range of possibilities, we chose in this work to examine in depth a particular set of strategies.

sections.heading: 5.3 Bidding with General Preferences
sections.text: The task dependency model represents relatively simple production capacities and benefits for consumers. At this point, we are discussing some natural potential extensions of the tendering guidelines to a broader class of skills and preferences. A producer who is able to produce variable units could offer just as if they were several identical producers. Such a producer would maintain separate offers for each unit in his tenders and update the individual offers independently of each other. Similarly, a consumer with additive value for several goods or several units of a product for each unit could offer as if it were a separate consumer. A producer with alternatives to some input factors can switch his offer to the currently cheapest option independently of other input factors. Subtle problems may arise for a producer who has alternative input sets, especially if he wins parts of the input sets on an experimental basis. An option would be to focus on the set with the lowest perceived costs, which may include a premium for goods that are not included in the winning group.

sections.heading: 6. Empirical Performance of SAMP-SB
sections.text: While our analysis results provide some insight into SAMP-SB and its variants, they do not support a comprehensive characterization of performance, with the exception of specific network structures in specific cases. To better understand the effectiveness of SAMP-SB and SAMP-SB-D, we conducted an empirical study based on random protocol simulations of dependency networks.

sections.text: Theorem 17. If a run of SAMP-SB in (V, E) is in a valid solution state (β β), so that: • each consumer c wins either an offer or p (g) + δb > vc (g) for all < g, c > E, • all agents have correct beliefs about what goods they are currently winning • all bids from consumers and active producers were received in response to current price quotations, • and no sales offers are lost due to a tie, then after the subsequent price offer from each auction the system will be in a quasi-calm state with a valid solution. Proof: Let the current prices be p. The current consumer supply policy dictates that consumers will not change their offers under the stated conditions. Since we have a valid solution, each producer is feasible and therefore does not increase any of their wholesale offers. Therefore, no agent will modify any purchase offer.

metadata.abstractText: Supply chain formation is the process of determining the structure and terms of exchange relationships to enable a multilevel, multiagent production activity. We present a simple model of supply chains, highlighting two characteristic features: hierarchical subtask decomposition, and resource contention. To decentralize the formation process, we introduce a market price system over the resources produced along the chain. In a competitive equilibrium for this system, agents choose locally optimal allocations with respect to prices, and outcomes are optimal overall. To determine prices, we define a market protocol based on distributed, progressive auctions, and myopic, non-strategic agent bidding policies. In the presence of resource contention, this protocol produces better solutions than the greedy protocols common in the artificial intelligence and multiagent systems literature. The protocol often converges to high-value supply chains, and when competitive equilibria exist, typically to approximate competitive equilibria. However, complementarities in agent production technologies can cause the protocol to wastefully allocate inputs to agents that do not produce their outputs. A subsequent decommitment phase recovers a significant fraction of the lost surplus.
